description: From Middle English ambiguite, from Old French ambiguite (French ambiguïté), from Latin ambiguitas, equivalent to ambiguous +‎ -ity.

entries.meaning: (countable) words or statements that are open to more than one interpretation, explanation or meaning, especially if that meaning cannot be determined from its context.
examples: His speech was made with such great ambiguity that neither supporter nor opponent could be certain of his true position.
